captions.text:
Catching someone in a lie? Not as easy as
you'd think!

Hey guys, Tara here for Dnews - and if you
have friends or partners who are chronic liars

- then you've come to the right place.
Nonverbal cues are widely considered to be

the most telling indicators of when a person
is lying. So what should you look out for?

One of the first signs of a nervous liar is
fidgeting - so pay close attention. Are they

shuffling their feet, or playing with their
hair, or messing with their watch? All of

these could be potential signs of deceit.
You've probably heard that liars tend to avoid

eye contact, but did you know that dilated
pupils can also be a sign? These are caused

by increased tension and concentration, typically
experienced when someone is lying.

Defensiveness is another telling behavior
- that can manifest in multiple ways. If someone's

voice suddenly gets higher, for example, that's
a pretty good giveaway. Liars also tend to

be uncooperative, and make more negative statements,
using words like "sad" and "hate."

Most of these seem pretty obvious when you
think about it - but modern research suggests

they may not be entirely accurate.
A study published last month in the journal

Psychological Science claims that humans are
better at detecting lies when they're doing

so unconsciously, rather than consciously
trying to decipher certain behaviors.

According to Maria Hartwig, a professor at
the John Jay College of Criminal Justice,

looking at a person's behavior and listening
to their statements - has a lie detection

accuracy rate of about 54%, which is only
slightly above the rate you'd obtain from

simply guessing.
The real indicators, she says, are much more

subtle than the nonverbal cues we've been
taught to rely on.

Clark Freshman is a law professor who runs
a firm that trains lawyers and negotiators

on proper lie detection techniques. He says
that while there's no surefire method for

detecting liars - there are some advanced
methods they employ during questioning.

The "unanticipated question approach," for
example, is useful in cases where you suspect

someone may be trying to cover something up.
This is based on the idea that people in these

situations, will often fabricate stories without
considering all of the details.

So, if someone commits a crime but their alibi
says they were at a restaurant when it happened

- ask them questions they wouldn't expect.
Like, where was the restaurant's bathroom

located? A person who's telling the truth,
will have no problem answering these details

- but a liar, might struggle more.
If you already have evidence that someone

has lied, Hartwig says the worst thing you
can do - is to let the liar know you have

evidence. Instead, ask them general questions,
and see how much information they're willing

to volunteer. People who are telling the truth,
tend to be more forthcoming with information

than liars, who are naturally evasive.
Freshman also says to look out for microexpressions

- which are subtle facial cues that appear
for only a split second. A 2008 study on the

topic, showed that people who are being deceptive
about their emotions, display inconsistent

expressions and blink more often than those
telling the truth.

So if you REALLY wanna catch someone in a
lie - try not to focus too much on the obvious

clues. It's the subtle ones that are usually
the most telling.

If you know any other tried-and-true methods
for catching a liar with their pants down

- let us know in the comments below, and for
more episodes of Dnews - subscribe here.

title: How To Tell If Someone Is Lying To You

comments.text:
I am heartily sick of these so called evidences of lying being presented as 
reliable. They never take into account other reasons than lying for these 
behaviors. People may fidget because they have a nervous disposition, or 
want to stop talking and get on with another task. They may avoid eye 
contact because they are uncomfortable with people or feel insignificant 
and unworthy. The list goes on and every behavior mentioned can have an 
alternate explanation than being a liar. And yet people take this garbage 
on board as truth and think they have an inside straight in analyzing 
people, and do great harm to people who may be innocent victims of someone 
who jumps to a wrong conclusion.﻿

I don't believe in this psychology bullshit. As a guideline maybe yes, but 
many people take it too literally and because of that they really think i'm 
lying when i'm actually telling the truth. Also i have bad social skills, 
even tho it gets better with getting older, so i sweat easily and such. 
Also i can't look in the eyes, i always look generally in the middle of 
people's faces. I also blink easily when there is cigarette smokes, too 
much dust, etc. especially in bars and dance clubs. So many people think 
i'm lying often and i really hate that cuz i'm really telling the truth 
most times. I'm not gonna say that i never lie, but you can understand my 
frustation. If you wanna know if someone is lying you have to caught them 
redhanded, period. The examples in this video really is for people you know 
really well (like family and close friends) or when they are suspicious too 
many times for it to be a coincedence. Same with the bathroom question, if 
the person didn't use the bathroom at all there is no reason he should know 
its exact location, that doesnt make him a lyer.﻿

comments.text:
Raising the voice, fake smile/overly happy for no apparent reason, trying 
to change the subject etc etc. In my experience there are many signs that 
someone is lying. 

A tip to tell if someone is lying is to ask the vital question, multiple 
times. If say your gf/bf did something which you know he/she won't tell you 
about, ask the question multiple times and watch the reaction. Liars 
usually get frustrated or angry when confronted with a touchy question. 
Because if they truly love you, they will feel bad when lying in your face, 
multiple times. ﻿

comments.text:
it just means you're nervous there's a difference between how a liar and a 
nervous person reacts, and even a lying nervous person. Micro-expressions 
are just ques that tell us someone is thinking of something, and are most 
often generalized with lying because that's what we're looking for. When 
you ask a person a question they're likely to do one if not all these 
things: Look away to the side usually to their bottom right or to your 
bottom left and also rub their hands or touch their face, depending on how 
personal the question is they may be guarded and you can tell if they 
either fold their arms or put their hands in their pockets, and if they're 
sitting they cross their legs. If they look to their bottom left or your 
bottom right they are probably trying to make something up and often times 
will shrug their shoulders with their hands in their pocket, most often 
they're making something up if they don't tell you right away they don't 
know. A socially awkward, nervous liar believe it or not can be quite calm 
when they lie as since they try over compensate for their nervousness, but 
that causes them a lot of stress, if you strike right away with the forward 
question that they are going to lie about they will look you in the eyes 
with a furrowed brow and answer hostilely, if you take your time and ask 
simple small questions the hostility won't be great but after a few it will 
be obvious of their growing hostility, their edge of their lip will rise 
upwards in animosity for a brief moment and then they'll start to break 
down and answer hastily and hostilely, and after answering as few questions 
as they seem fit they will try to leave the conversation right away and any 
more question asking after they want to leave they'll take as harassment 
you should by that point figure something is up. Also a good thing about 
Micro-expressions is that the person doing it doesn't realize they're doing 
it, I've garnered much success and failure in this art with experimentation 
or "field study", if you're not a Sadistic person you start to feel guilty 
being able to read people, even sad that people are so easily read, which 
will makes you feel distrustful of yourself, don't go into this thing 
haphazardly you'll only hurt yourself and without proper knowledge start to 
feel paranoid of the gazes of people. You'll learn general stuff about this 
in your year one psych class in college.
